bibl.title: Letter from H. B. Richardson to Michael E. Connor, August 21, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302020]

div1.p: Richardson sends Connor a report describing an ongoing investigation into a death in Colima, Mexico, that initially received a post mortem diagnosis of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from H. B. Richardson to Michael E. Connor, August 21, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302020]
div1.p:
Today I sent the following telegram addressed to
you at Tampico, Veracruz and Mexico City:

“Suspected case of yellow fever presented itself
today. Autopsy by Dr. Galindo. Section of liver
on way to Department. Am writing”.

The deceased Luis Villalobos Corona left Manzanillo
for Colima on August 13, 1923, in apparent good health. He
had been employed in Manzanillo as a mechanic on a Government
launch.

He was seen yesterday about 3 P.M. by Doctor Ciro
Hurtado of this city who found him in a moribund condition with
hemmorahges from the mouth and rectum. Death ensued the same
night and today Doctor Hurtado gave a Certificate of yellow
fever.

Knowledge of these occurences were conveyed to this
office by a Reportor of the “Informador”, a Newspaper published
in Guadalajara, who came here looking for more detailed informa-
tion.

I immediately saw this Doctor who confirmed the rumor
stating that he was not positive that it was yellow fever, but
that the bloody stools and vomitus had caused him to make that
diagnosis.

Thereupon I went in search of Doctor Galindo Medico
Delegado in this city and found that he had received no advise
of the matter.

We instantly proceeded to the Cemetery arriving just
as the body was being lowered into the grave. A partial autopsy
was performed and a section of Liver removed, which specimen has
been sent to the Department preserved in ten per cent Formalin
solution.

The body was viewed by us at exactly one thirty P.M.
or twelve to fifteen hours after death had occured. There was
an entire absence of yellowness, the nasal passages were com-
pletely clogged by a profuse amount of bright red blood, the
abdomen being enormously distended the intestines were pricked
as they presented themselves in the incision and I was able to
note a quite extensive amount of altered blood, perfectly black,
the liver was small and hard and upon cross-section it appeared
cirrhotic.

I have asked Doctor Hurtado to write me a letter giving
me his impressions of what he saw when he visited the deceased.
When I possess this information copies will be sent to you and to
the Departmento.

The deceased met his death at 451 Calle Belisario Dom-
inguez which is located two blocks from the R/R Station.

The block in which he lived and died was personally
inspected this evening. It is composed of twelve houses and no
Mosquito breeding was found.

While the personnel has not been increased every-
thing possible is being done to increase anti-larvae activity
and especially in the district immediately surrounding the
suspected residence.

As soon as I may I shall proceed to Munzanillo as
there are apparently well founded rumors that this man was a
pronounced alcoholic and I am anxious to confirm them.

Doctor Galindo informed me that he did not consider
the case as one of yellow fever.
div1.closer:
Very truly, (Signed) H. B. Richardson.
P. S. Next attached please find c. c. my report to the
Departamento. You no doubt have now seen original.
H.B.R.
Dr. M. E. Connor
Acting Director
Calle Rivera #16
Tampico, Tamps.
